main event: On November 6, 1957, in Buffalo, New York, a bright, round, and very bright object was observed in the sky, making erratic movements and changing in size before disappearing from view after a 21 1/2 minute observation.
interesting points: The object was first noticed as a bright star-like object before making erratic movements and changing in size, with no sound heard during the sighting.
The observation lasted for 13.13 miles, indicating the distance over which the object was observed.
The sighting concluded with the note that more data was needed for evaluation and location purposes.
Another report from Buffalo, New York, attributes a similar light in the sky to the planet Venus, similar to a phenomenon described by the Air Force in Project Blue Book.

An older report from September 22, 1950, describes a witness in Buffalo, New York, observing a round, hovering object emitting a bright orange light at an elevation of approximately 1000 feet, which then moved off rapidly to the southeast and disappeared from view.
sighted object: bright, round, very bright object making erratic movements in the sky
photographs: no, the reports do not include photographs
